hoverInfo.quick: The chief god of the Tuatha De Danann, master of druidry, wielder of the club of life and death, and owner of the inexhaustible cauldron.

listDisplay.expandedContent: The Dagda is the supreme father god of the Tuatha De Danann in Irish mythology. Known as the 'Good God' for his skill in all arts, he wields three sacred treasures: the inexhaustible Cauldron of Plenty, the mighty Club that kills with one end and resurrects with the other, and the Uaithne harp that controls the seasons and emotions.
listDisplay.primary: The Dagda - The Good God, Father of All
listDisplay.secondary: Chief god of the Tuatha De Danann, master of druidry, abundance, and the cycle of life and death.

subtitle: The Good God, Father of All
name: The Dagda

sections.title: Description
sections.content: The Dagda is the supreme father god of Irish mythology and chief of the Tuatha De Danann, the divine race that ruled Ireland before the coming of the Milesians. His name means 'The Good God' - not in a moral sense, but indicating his proficiency in all skills. He is the master of druidry, wielder of immense magical power, and embodies the fertile abundance of the earth.

sections.title: The Three Sacred Treasures
sections.content: The Dagda possesses three legendary items: The Coire Ansic (Cauldron of Plenty) that never empties and satisfies all who eat from it; the Lorg Mor (Great Club) so heavy it must be wheeled on wheels, which kills with one end and resurrects with the other; and Uaithne, the living harp whose music controls the seasons and can make listeners weep, laugh, or fall into enchanted sleep.

sections.title: Role in the Mythological Cycle
sections.content: The Dagda plays a central role in the Mythological Cycle of Irish literature. Before the Second Battle of Mag Tuired against the Fomorians, he mated with the Morrigan at the river Unius on Samhain, securing her aid in battle. He later negotiated with the Fomorians and was humiliated by being forced to eat an enormous porridge from a giant hole in the ground, yet he emerged victorious in the subsequent battle.

metadata.period: Iron Age through Medieval (c. 500 BCE - 1200 CE in oral tradition)

description: The Dagda is the supreme father god of Irish mythology and chief of the Tuatha De Danann. Known as 'The Good God' for his mastery of all skills, he wields the Cauldron of Plenty that never empties, the Club of Life and Death, and the magical harp Uaithne. He embodies druidry, abundance, fertility, and the cycle of life and death, serving as the archetypal father figure of Celtic religion.
symbols: Club of Life and Death (Lorg Mor)

primarySources: Cath Maige Tuired (Battle of Mag Tuired)

mythsAndLegends.title: The Second Battle of Mag Tuired
mythsAndLegends.summary: Before the great battle against the Fomorians, the Dagda met the Morrigan at the river Unius on Samhain. Their union secured the war goddess's aid for the Tuatha De Danann. The Dagda also negotiated with the Fomorians and endured humiliation, forced to eat an enormous porridge from a pit, yet led his people to victory.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Theft of the Harp
mythsAndLegends.summary: After the Fomorians stole his harp Uaithne, the Dagda pursued them with Lugh and Ogma. When they found the harp hanging in the Fomorian hall, the Dagda called to it and it flew to his hands, killing nine Fomorians. He then played the three strains: the strain of sorrow, the strain of joy, and the strain of sleep, allowing them to escape.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Dagda and Boann
mythsAndLegends.summary: The Dagda's affair with Boann, wife of Elcmar, resulted in the birth of Aengus Og. To conceal the pregnancy, the Dagda held the sun still for nine months so that Aengus was conceived and born in a single day.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Loss of Bru na Boinne
mythsAndLegends.summary: The Dagda gave his son Aengus the great burial mound of Newgrange (Bru na Boinne) after Aengus tricked him through clever wordplay, asking for 'a day and a night' which in Irish could mean 'day and night' - that is, forever.

corpusQueries.description: Search as leader of the divine race

worship.temples: No specific temples survived, but sacred sites like Newgrange may have been associated with his cult
worship.practices: Druidic rituals, seasonal celebrations, harvest festivals

iconography.appearance: Often depicted as a large, powerful figure, sometimes corpulent, wearing a short tunic
iconography.attributes: Carries the great club and cauldron, sometimes shown with the harp
iconography.posture: Standing with club or seated at feast

conversionContext.description: The Dagda ('Good God') was a chief figure in Irish mythology. Christian Ireland preserved Dagda myths in medieval manuscripts while framing them as pre-Christian history rather than active religion.
conversionContext.significance: Irish monks' preservation of mythology demonstrates a particular Christian approach: recording cultural heritage while denying its religious validity.

typologicalConnections.observation: The Dagda's role as 'Father of All' parallels Father-god imagery in many traditions.
typologicalConnections.distinction: Celtic father gods are part of pantheons; the biblical Father is one God with Son and Spirit.

typologicalConnections.observation: The Dagda's cauldron of plenty parallels God's providential care and Eucharistic imagery.
typologicalConnections.distinction: The cauldron is a magical object; Christian provision comes from God's gracious action. The Eucharist commemorates Christ's sacrifice, not magical abundance.

scholarlyEnrichment.methodology: Comprehensive mythological expansion with primary sources and cross-cultural connections
